close_symbols: All callers (call sites) of MHD_str_pct_decode_lenient_n_ and the call-site contexts (actual/provable ranges/values of pct_encoded_len, buf_size, decoded pointer and broken_encoding pointer)
Implementation (and any globals) used by toxdigitvalue
explanation:
toxdigitvalue: The function’s control flow and side effects depend on the return of toxdigitvalue (negative indicates non-hex digit and changes the taken branch). You must inspect its implementation to know whether it can have side effects (modify globals, errno, memory) that make writes such as *broken_encoding or decoded[w] observable — if it has side effects, removing code may change behaviour, so the code may not be dead.

MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE (preprocessor macro): The #ifndef around the fast-path makes that entire block compile-time conditional. To decide whether that block is present (and thus potentially dead or live) you must know the build configuration (definition of this macro). If it is always defined in the project configuration the fast-path is never compiled; if it is never defined the slow-path/path duplication might be redundant; the macro determines whether code is actually present.

All callers (call sites) of MHD_str_pct_decode_lenient_n_ and their call-site contexts: Dead-code analysis requires knowing how the function is used — specifically whether particular branches are reachable or whether their observable effects (writes to decoded buffer or *broken_encoding) matter to callers. You must examine every caller to determine whether parameters (pct_encoded_len and buf_size) can make one branch always taken (making the other branch removable without changing program behaviour) and whether callers inspect broken_encoding/decoded contents. If the static call graph shows no callers you must still search the project (or build) for indirect/weak-linked call sites or uses.

Implementation (and any globals) used by toxdigitvalue: If toxdigitvalue itself references project globals or other functions with side effects, those symbols must be inspected because they can make operations inside MHD_str_pct_decode_lenient_n_ observable even when they look redundant (for MISRA dead-code purposes a write or side-effect that would be observed by other code means the code is not dead).
